article.name: Troubleshooting: Users Receive Error Message When Opening PDF Attachments
article.title: Troubleshooting: Users Receive Error Message When Opening PDF Attachments
article.body:
If your users are receiving a Security Block error message when opening PDF attachments from a phishing campaign, you can edit your settings in Adobe Reader, Acrobat, or Document Cloud to whitelist KnowBe4 and allow that connection to occur.

The screenshot below is an example of a Security Block error message.

To make sure users do not receive this error message, you can configure Adobe to automatically trust websites from your Win OS Security Zones. Then, you'll need to add KnowBe4's domains to your Windows Trusted Sites by using Group Policy. For more information, see the steps below:

  1. Make sure Adobe is configured to automatically trust websites from my Win OS Security Zones. You can find this setting by navigating to Edit > Preferences > Security (Enhanced) > Privileged Locations. Then, select the check box next to Automatically trust sites from my Win OS security zones. This check box is selected by default. 
  2. Add our phish domains and the hostnames listed below to your Windows Trusted Sites. You can add these by using your Group Policy. To find a list of phish domains, navigate to Phishing > Domains in your KSAT console. For more information, see our How to Manage Phish Link Domains article.
    • knowbe4.com
    • phishtest.knowbe4.com

images.alt:
This image displays a standard Windows-style security alert dialog box titled **"Security Block."**

**Content Details:**

*   **Icon:** A standard yellow warning triangle containing an exclamation mark.
*   **Message Body:** The primary text states the security action taken by the software: "Acrobat does not allow connection to: phishtest.knowbe4.com"
*   **Application Context:** The message indicates that the connection attempt was blocked by the Acrobat application.

**User Interface Controls:**

The lower right corner contains two action buttons:

1.  **Help** (Currently highlighted/selected)
2.  **OK**

The screenshot below is an example of a Security Block error message.

images.alt:
This image displays the **Preferences** dialog box within **Adobe Reader**, specifically accessing the **Security (Enhanced)** configuration pane.

**1. Application and Context:**

*   **Application:** Adobe Reader.
*   **Dialog Title:** Preferences.
*   **Selected Category:** Security (Enhanced) is highlighted in the left-hand **Categories** navigation list.

**2. Categories Navigation Pane (Left):**

The left panel lists configuration categories, including standard entries such as Commenting, Documents, General, 3D & Multimedia, Accessibility, Internet, Language, Multimedia (legacy), Reading, Search, Security, Signatures, and Updater.

**3. Settings Pane (Right):**

The right panel is divided into three main security configuration sections:

### A. Sandbox Protections

*   **Checkbox:** "Enable Protected Mode at startup" (Checked).
*   **Checkbox:** "Create Protected Mode log file" (Unchecked).
*   **Action Button:** "View log."
*   **Protected View Group (Radio Buttons):**
    *   "Off" (Selected).
    *   "Files from potentially unsafe locations" (Unselected).
    *   "All files" (Unselected).

### B. Enhanced Security

*   **Checkbox:** "Enable Enhanced Security" (Checked).
*   **Checkbox:** "Cross domain log file" (Unchecked).
*   **Action Button:** "View."

### C. Privileged Locations

This section includes instructional text describing the purpose of Privileged Locations (selectively trusting files, folders, and hosts to bypass security restrictions).

*   **Checkbox 1:** "Automatically trust documents with valid certification" (Unchecked).
*   **Checkbox 2:** "Automatically trust sites from my Win OS security zones" (Checked).
*   **Action Button:** "View Windows Trusted Sites."
*   A large, empty list box is displayed for managing trusted locations.
*   **Management Buttons (Bottom):** "Add File," "Add Folder Path," "Add Host." The "Remove" button is present but greyed out.

**4. Footer Elements:**

*   **Hyperlinks:** Three blue hyperlinks provide contextual help: "What is Protected View?", "What is Enhanced Security?", and "What are Privileged Locations?".
*   **Action Buttons:** "OK" and "Cancel."
images.context: This check box is selected by default.

images.alt:
The image displays the **Internet Options** configuration dialog box, specifically the **Security** tab.

**Zone Selection:**
The dialog presents four security zones: Internet, Local intranet, **Trusted sites** (currently selected and highlighted), and Restricted sites. A description box, marked by a large green checkmark, confirms that the **Trusted sites** zone contains websites trusted not to damage the computer. An active **Sites** button is present for managing the list of trusted URLs.

**Security Level Configuration:**
The section "Security level for this zone" indicates that allowed levels are "All." A vertical slider control is set to the **Medium** security level. The description for the Medium level lists two actions:
1. Prompts before downloading potentially unsafe content.
2. Unsigned ActiveX controls will not be downloaded.

Below the slider, an unchecked checkbox labeled **Enable Protected Mode (requires restarting Internet Explorer)** is visible.

**Action Buttons (Zone/Level Management):**
Three buttons control security level settings:
*   **Custom level...** (Active)
*   **Default level** (Inactive/Grayed out)
*   **Reset all zones to default level** (Inactive/Grayed out, located beneath the level buttons)

**Dialog Controls:**
Standard controls at the bottom of the window include **OK** (highlighted/selected), **Cancel**, and **Apply** (Inactive/Grayed out).
